title: Finally something good coming out of the Lore Team
body:
All the Azir-Sivir material is awesome, I love it.
They don't live in the institute of war 24/7 and this story is showing that great stuff can still happen. Do I say thanks or congrats? I don't know but well done guys, you did **something** right

I'll edit this right away, I meant great things can be done with this lore/old lore

replies.body:
The animated part was way better than the glassthingy part. I just hope they will address Xeraths side of the story before or at the end of the event. Otherwise he's stuck with a generic villain story that isn't quite Xerath *ahem Trundle ahem*. 

It does seem that the format is really shortening things. I feel like things are missing due to it being a video, similar to a movie adaptation of a book, but without a book to find the details in. The movie is coherent, but everything from the book that wasn't needed to make the movie coherent was left out. Perhaps it's because all the things don't feel very impactful (Sivir almost died, Azir ascended, the city just rose from the sands), lack of build-up perhaps? Hard to say for me. At least things are happening, unlike Freljord.

(off-topic, I do hope Riot will go back to Trundle, his in-game voice-overs are entirely unlike his old lore and it makes me unable to fully delve into this new lore)

yeah what they did the trundles look/story was absolutely disgusting to me as a s2 trundle player.
And then they had the balls to nerf all AOE slows to canceling the moment you leave the AOE and the refresh rate of the slow was nerfed as well.

Sad day for all singed/trundle players.
Think that was the same patch that gutted singed E/R as well.
Meh the story is rather lackluster to me. Maybe it's the script, but it's to.cheesey with things like the blade is the key and she betrays sivir

Plus she's a mercenary, one of if not *the* best around. Surely she's had some deals go sour in the past, she should have been ready. 

And did Cassiopeia even bother to *ask*? I'm sure Sivir would've handed over her blade for a minute or two for some extra dough.

Sivir is certainly used to deals going bad, but even the best can be left vulnerable. She was distracted for just a moment by the realization that the family heirloom she was carrying was somehow tied into the secrets of an entire lost empire. Cass knew what she was there for, and it wasn't to share untold power and riches with some expendable peon. The promise of new power was destined, in her eyes, to bolster herself, the Du Couteaus and Noxus. 

Sivir was caught off-guard, Cass knew when to strike.

> Sivir is certainly used to deals going bad, but even the best can be left vulnerable. She was distracted for just a moment by the realization that the family heirloom she was carrying was somehow tied into the secrets of an entire lost empire. Cass knew what she was there for, and it wasn't to share untold power and riches with some expendable peon. The promise of new power was destined, in her eyes, to bolster herself, the Du Couteaus and Noxus. 
> 
> Sivir was caught off-guard, Cass knew when to strike.

Except we're unaware that Sivir is a *peon* now. Previously, she was the Battle Mistress the title which was bestowed *by* Noxus. Also the video makes no mention of the weapon being a family heirloom. There's a old empire nearby, I can't believe it wasn't looted hardcore since it's fall, no reason to think Sivir is part of any special bloodline til you guys spell it out at the end.  Ancient weapon doesn't automatically equal family heirloom since we have no history of it's providence. 

Distracted? I guess I can see it when I go back and watch it AFTER reading your comment, but I don't think the video doesn't reflect that well since I didn't pick up on it previously, and I watched it a couple times. 

If the new lore medium is going to be more video you can certainly step up your game on the dialog. The visuals are mostly great.

ehr
everybody is a peon for Cassiopeia, if it is not a noble. Duh.
To me it seemed like the entire place was buried and/or in ruins. Upon Azir's ascendance, the city got its second wind, restoring its place above the sands.

I have a few problems with this.

How did Sivir ever come to be under the impression the item she held was a weapon to begin with? And how did Cassiopeia know the 'weapon's' significance when even Sivir herself didn't? But the biggest problem of all I have is...

While I can understand Cassiopeia prioritizing power for her family, Sivir is still Noxian, and a valuable one at that, or at least she was as recently as her rework which is when the first hints of this storyline were dropped.  Yes, her ancestors may be from Shurima, but that was centuries if not millenia ago, which is plenty of time to relocate and assimilate into another culture.  Or is Sivir not supposed to be Noxian anymore?  Certainly the first video implied that she wasn't, which...  Honestly if that's the case I'm just losing even more faith in the lore team.  Because what's the point in getting invested in any part of this fictional world you've created if every single detail of the story is liable to change from one moment to the next without any warning, or even reason?

I agree; they were cheesy and indicative of poor writing.  This is a matter of telling versus showing a story. Some parts of the videos just 'told' us what was happening like a dull script. Other parts ***showed*** us what was happening through more fanciful wordplay or through the art and animations. The Lore team needs to do a better job of ***showing*** us the lore instead of just telling it to us.

> Meh the story is rather lackluster to me. Maybe it's the script, but it's to.cheesey with things like the blade is the key and she betrays sivir

THE ANCIENT BLADE IS A KEY!

SHE ... BETRAYS SIVIR!

I still can't make myself watch the new vid with sound on for more than a few seconds. Using the new "echo filter dog-man" Nasus voice just makes it worse.

That said, I liked the latter part of the video. I think it's great that Shurima is starting to get some more love.

I honestly feel like the story is a bit cliched, tbh. And there are a lot of things about it that don't make sense, though perhaps that's because we don't have the full picture yet.

- Where's Nasus? Did he just up and leave the tomb after it was sealed? Does he have no idea that Renekton and Xerath are now free?
- Why did Renekton go insane, but Xerath didn't? Seemed to me like they'd kick the shit out of each other while sealed in the tomb
- Cassiopeia is a diplomat and a deceiver, not an assassin. Du Couteau the Eldest might have stuck Sivir with a sword, but it makes no sense that Cass would have tried
- Azir randomly ascends because he saves his great-great-great granddaughter. Just why.
 -Because Azir ascends, the entirety of Shurima comes back to life. Again, why.
- Sivir is now a Disney princess. Next video will probably have her singing a musical number about how she wants more from life.

I'm hoping things get better as the Riot lore team adjusts to their new environment, but right now everything smacks of being thrown together a bit sloppily.

* Nasus was consumed by grief at the apparent loss of his brother. It's been an extremely long time since that happened and Shurima's return, so Nasus has been elsewhere. One could believe that Nasus might see Shurima as the tombstone for everything he had fought for, both before and after his own Ascension.
* Renekton went insane as he had Xerath getting into his head for a very long time. I wouldn't recommend it, it makes you twitch after a while.
* Indeed Cassiopeia is a master of using deception and manipulation rather than the blade, but she's also the daughter of one of the most formidable martial experts in Noxus â€” and the rest of her family isn't too shabby either. Cass knows how to handle a blade, she was just having to use alternative methods due to being on unfamiliar territory. She stepped out of her comfort zone for the good of the Du Couteaus and Noxus (though primarily herself, of course) and thought she'd pulled it off to perfection. There were just a few aspects of Shurima that even her considerable charms had been unable to uncover beforehand. A little knowledge is an extremely dangerous thing.
* Azir saves his descendant within the waters that mark the birthplace of Shurima's capital, a city that once ensured life and prosperity for countless thousands in one of Runeterra's most inhospitable places. I can't be too specific due to spoilers, but Shurima is far more than a great place to vacation (insert beach front property gag here), and it takes more than great aqueducts to make a civilization like that possible. Shurima's rebirth, Azir's Ascension and Sivir's return from the severely iron-deficient are all part of one truth.
* Sivir's got a bloody awful singing voice. It's quite shocking really. She sounds like a cat in a gravel mixer. Her next song would probably have something to do with what she'll do to Cass when she catches up with her.
So are we expecting some follow up to the Shurima story? You're not going to leave us high and dry like Freljord, right?

uhm, I understand that Renekton's change is what makes him the champion we know today, so it's important to write about it and I think people is grateful for knowing what drove Renekton mad. The story about how he ascended would be confusing for new players at best but I think Nasus is in a different spot...

Nasus hasn't changed much since he ascended I think, he's wiser and more experienced in battle now but aside from that he's been pretty much the same... am I right? he's... a guardian, he's always been a guardian, even when he was an alien xD, but we don't know what his motives are in the grand scheme... I mean, it raises several questions in my head:

1.- why does he guards Shurima so vigorously? 
2.- why did he let Renekton jump in instead of jumping himself if he's the guardian he says he is? 
3.- Who is Nasus? besides a guardian of course, does he process information like a human being? or perhaps from being ascended for too long you loose yourself to the godly state?
4.-How and why was he ascended? (this is the most important one, since it tells us who Nasus is, like Azir and unlike Renekton)

thanks in advance!

>Renekton went insane as he had Xerath getting into his head for a very long time. I wouldn't recommend it, it makes you twitch after a while.

I don't know, I always thought Xerath was just this lightning or energy guy. The most I could imagine Xerath doing is giving him a light jolt now and again. His dialogue never struck me as a Hannibal Lecture type of champion. That'd be closer to Malzahar or perhaps Karthus personality and power wise (Malefic Vision).


> Sivir's got a bloody awful singing voice. 

Hey, that didn't stop Mulan and Pocahontas!

Hmm.

1. Why does the serpent trap not kill Cassiopeia outright? Why does it fuse to her (presumably granting her her powers) instead?
2. Why didn't one of his descendants try to resurrect Azir *earlier*?  What exactly is required for resurrrection magic?
3. Wouldn't Azir's soul have gone to wherever souls went before the Shadow Isles breached the boundary between life and death, instead of outright to oblivion?
4. Why doesn't Azir have interactions (even less serious ones) with the other minion-mancers and Karthus [in the same vein as his Urgot interactions]? ;_;
5. How does Nasus know of what went on in the tomb?

> * Nasus was consumed by grief at the apparent loss of his brother. It's been an extremely long time since that happened and Shurima's return, so Nasus has been elsewhere. One could believe that Nasus might see Shurima as the tombstone for everything he had fought for, both before and after his own Ascension.

Just imagine how Nasus will react to all of this suddenly happening. Or even how Azir will react to finding out what became of Renekton. Perhaps now that he is ascended Azir can begin the task of unwarping Renekton's mind. I can just see the wake that Nasus making his way to the new Shurima would leave behind it. That and the epic clashes it would take to bring Renekton back into the fold of the Resurrected Empire.

First time in a long time I can say that anything lore with LoL has struck a chord :-)
What freaking "spoilers" please dont let us dry

Xerath drove him nuts over the time they were locked up, probably to fill the time,

Diplomat from Noxus, that last part is pretty important,

I'm pretty sure he ascended because he was now worthy of it, It showed simple humility and compassion, and what ever powers control the process decided he was ready for the power, Also he put the city back together, Remember he is pretty much a god, at least on par with Xerath,

More likely she will be the leader of Shurima's special forces,

Yeah, I'm liking the direction the lore is taking. I still feel sad over the fact that summoners are no longer a thing so I feel a bit disconnected from the game but I look forward as to what will come in the future. My only worry is whether that is going to be in the near future or if they are going to make us wait 6 months for something like this again.
I can understand that concern. We've got a lot of catching up to do and trust to earn. I'm fortunate to work with phenomenal people who are striving to do just that. Shurima is step one.

I respect the team that is trying to clean up the mess that has been made.  Only thing you guys can do is keep producing content instead of just letting everything drop again.  I'm cheering for yall and hoping.

That's what our focus is: producing content and leveling it up. We've got a lot to do, but we believe we're heading in the right direction to  expand upon a world rich with story possibilities.

Cheers.
I can't wait to see more stories and events, it has so much potential. But the retcon is going to leave a hole which cannot ever be filled.

> I can understand that concern. We've got a lot of catching up to do and trust to earn. I'm fortunate to work with phenomenal people who are striving to do just that. Shurima is step one.

What I'm worried about is that the only comments from Narrative are going to be on cherry-picked from extremely positive posts.  There are a number of comments and concerns on the Lore forums (mine included) that should be addressed by a Red at some point in the very near future.

To be fair, there was a thread about a week ago that wasn't positive and someone from Narrative was posting.  It ended in death threats and calling for that person to be fired, so I'm not entirely surprised that Riot's a little hesitant of dealing with those threads.

> To be fair, there was a thread about a week ago that wasn't positive and someone from Narrative was posting.  It ended in death threats and calling for that person to be fired, so I'm not entirely surprised that Riot's a little hesitant of dealing with those threads.

To be fair, that Rioter came into a thread, on a forum that Narrative had treated with silence for 15 months, gave an inappropriate movie quote and a dismissive comment.  That Rioter then went on Twitter and misconstrued what happened and had to come back to explain herself.

The death threats and calls to have her fired went WAY overboard, no argument.  But for Riot to say "It's too tough to say anything there" when they created that situation (their admission) with their silence, empty promises and big changes without explanation in the past is just pathetic.

They created a big mess out of that forum, and they should be willing to work at cleaning it up.

>The death threats and calls to have her fired went WAY overboard, no argument.

Yep.  Just think, though; even if there were mistakes made, what incentive is there for Riot to continue participating in such ridiculously negative environments when there are places they can have legitimate conversation and not have to worry about that crap?

>for Riot to say "It's too tough to say anything there" when they created that situation (their admission) with their silence, empty promises and big changes without explanation in the past

I agree with you here, but it's also technically true.  Regardless of whether Riot brought it upon themselves (let's be real, at least part of the problem has indeed been Riot), it really *is* tough for them to say anything there.  Years of animosity have built up, and diving right into it is like a death wish.

That being said, there is some merit in "ripping off the band-aid" as it were.  There will likely be a lot of negativity and rage at the onset, but with the right approach it should be cathartic rather than toxic.

> >The death threats and calls to have her fired went WAY overboard, no argument.
> 
> Yep.  Just think, though; even if there were mistakes made, what incentive is there for Riot to continue participating in such ridiculously negative environments when there are places they can have legitimate conversation and not have to worry about that crap?

Because the most hardcore fans, the ones who suffered through all the broken promises, ham-fisted changes and long bouts of silence, are still in that forum trying to get responses from Riot.  Those are the fans who still care enough, despite all the reasons to the contrary, to want to work with Narrative to improve the product.  Those are the people who will sell the retcon to other fans, not a pretty Dev Blog full of more promises and more begging for trust when the've not earned the right to ask.

Imagine how much better Shurima could have been if Narrative had a better relationship with their fans?  More back and forth from us to help improve everything.  A simple "What do you think of Cassiopeia" thread would have improved things by leaps in bounds (imogdo).

>

Regardless of whether Riot brought it upon themselves (let's be real, at least part of the problem has indeed been Riot), it really *is* tough for them to say anything there.  Years of animosity have built up, and diving right into it is like a death wish.
>

I am a reporter/journalist.  I make part of my living dealing with PR firms who have to put a positive spin on far bigger issues than Narrative's failures.

I could teach Narrative how to fix the situation over there and get the healing process started.  I wouldn't do it for free, though.

>Because the most hardcore fans, the ones who suffered through all the broken promises, ham-fisted changes and long bouts of silence, are still in that forum trying to get responses from Riot. Those are the fans who still care enough, despite all the reasons to the contrary, to want to work with Narrative to improve the product. Those are the people who will sell the retcon to other fans, not a pretty Dev Blog full of more promises and more begging for trust when the've not earned the right to ask.

Well-written.

While this is true, these are also the fans who apparently consider the solution to this communication issue to be utterly destroying the person that took the time to address them in the first place.

Regardless, I think I misspoke.  I absolutely agree that there is tons of merit in discussing things with the most passionate section of the community, not disputing that at all.  The key point here is that harsh negativity and slander aren't avenues through which we as a community and Riot as a company can come together and fix this relationship.  

Constructive criticism is fine, but when it mutates into outright hostility it's not healthy comunication.  From a PR/interaction perspective, it's usually most beneficial to find a place to communicate where there is mutual passion and both parties can start from basic understanding.  It doesn't need to be positive, necessarily, but it can't be completely toxic because no conversation will mean anything.

>I make part of my living dealing with PR firms who have to put a positive spin on far bigger issues than Narrative's failures.

This isn't necessarily related, but Riot isn't super interested in spin; they want trust and meaningful two-way communication.  Admittedly, this hasn't exactly gone to plan...

I just wish it explained why things happened? Why did Azir awakening suddenly lead to him being a bird god?
Why all the deus ex machinas to tell the story?
She just happens to be a descendant, have the key, and bleed onto the right seal.
There just happens to be a water of life pool.
Why would any of that lead to armies being awakened and his empire reforming itself?

The cinematic was very VERY good looking, but the narration felt way too blunt and awkward, and I still don't know why things happened the way they did.

I'm afraid that this is going to become the standard, that the lore is being dumbed down with more deus ex machinas and black/white heroes and villains.

> All the Azir-Sivir material is awesome, I love it.
> They don't live in the institute of war 24/7 and this story is showing that great stuff can still happen. Do I say thanks or congrats? I don't know but well done guys, you did **something** right
> 
> I'll edit this right away, I meant great things can be done with this lore/old lore

Cheers, I'm glad you enjoyed it. This is just the first step of our renewed journey through Runeterra, we hope you'll enjoy what's to come.

So... unlike the shadow isles, and the freljord event... Is anything going to come out of this? Or are we just going to ignore everything that happened again, and move onto the next event? What about the longer lores that would be on the website? When will we get that? A couple of sentences =/= good lore. Especially Skarner, who's lost his entire identity.

Honestly, I just hope that they find a way to convey *little* things as well. A thing that I REALLY liked in the JoJ (I know, Riot hates that with all fibers in it's body, but bear with me) was that it related the big things, like the Kalamanda debacle and the revolt of Ionia, to the small things, like Annie being a poster girl for a tooth paste brand. You might say that it's stupid, I say that it makes the world more believable. I LIKE when stupid things happen in a fictional universe, because guess what, that's what happens in the real world. Yeah, I like hearing about how Azir got his empire back, but I'd also like to learn about a bar fight that Gangplank got into because Gragas wouldn't show him the proper respect, or how Gnar caused all sorts of trouble in Bramble City, or Lulu pretending to be Veigar's evil minion and getting in all sorts of "evil schemes" with him, or Jayce getting ran over by an army of bowling balls, or Jayce being forced to smear butter all over Urgot, or Jayce stepping on a lego brick in a rake factory.

I totally agree about the little things, but it seems unlikely with the way they've written the lore so far. 

"Sivir is stunned with horror" Why is Sivir, the battle-hardened, legendary blade-wielding mercenary horrified when her sell swords die? I would assume her sell swords die every time they go on an adventure, she should be used to it by now, no?

"The ancient weapon is a key. Cassiopeia betrays Sivir. She picks up Sivir's blade, puts it into the lock."

A happens. B happens. C happens. that's not very good storytelling, and even in that tiny fraction of the story, there aren't little details. How does Cass betray Sivir? We assume she stabbed her somehow, because she's bleeding afterwards. 

Cass "sees only the statue of a huge serpent silently guarding the door to the tomb of the Emperors and smiles". Why is she smiling? What makes her think the HUGE SERPENT GUARDIAN won't do anything?? 

  Cass gets pinned in the jaws of a Temple guardian, and "the venom sears her flesh like acid" (weird simile) How does this not kill her? Why does a Temple guardian's acid/venom turn her into a being similar in power to Ascendants? How does she get out of its jaws?  How does Sivir's blood get to Azir? Why isn't Azir dead? He never ascended, so what is keeping him alive? Where the heck do Renekton and Xerath go? Two immensely powerful beings come bursting out of a tomb after centuries and completely ignore the people who released them? Why isn't Nasus guarding the place instead of some giant serpent that turns people into Ascendants? 

So many questions, so many details that are ignored. When you can't even get a "she stabbed her with a knife", I highly doubt we'll ever get anything as cool as Lulu pretending to be Veigar's evil minion, or anything of that miniscule a detail.

Writer's who build a story shouldn't be allowed to just back out of it entirely because they felt they wrote themselves into a corner. Write yourself OUT of the corner. This retconning is just really lazy.

IoW is too powerful? Have some void monsters come and kidnap all the summoners, throwing the world into chaos. You don't need motivations for Void creatures other than CHAOS AND DESTRUCTION. Maybe the Void God wants to see Runeterra thrown into chaos and laugh at our suffering. Maybe Summoner's are just peons for greater powers. Maybe ANYTHING. But just erasing everything already written? I seriously can't understand the logic behind this lore decision.

Yeah, all this retconning reeks of laziness to me. I don't know why they couldn't just disband the League. It still would have sucked, but at least it would have been continuing the story instead of "I'm bored with this story, let's write a completely different one".

I mean, why care about anything if the writer is just going to erase everything from existence? They might be rewriting Urgot to be a poor injusticed soul turned into a monster by an evil witch and can only go back to who he was with the kiss of a Princess or some shit, instead of the disgusting monster full of pain and rage who really just looks as ugly on the outside as he did inside that I love.

I wouldn't call it "good."  More like "something."

Criticisms:
1)  Sivir and Cassiopeia are transformed into Lara Croft and Jacqueline Natla (Tomb Raider).
2)  The traps that destroy Sivir's army is straight out of "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade."
3)  The flowing blood was ripped out of God of War 2.
4)  The final cinematic felt like something out of a PlayStation RPG cutscene.
5)  Nasus's voice actor is awesome.
6)  Xerath has been transformed from an interesting character into a clone of Jafar from *Aladdin.*
7)  The story is, once again, incomplete.  Azir ascends into "Armored Bird Guy" and then... end.  The ending of "The Sopranos" told us more.

I just hope it's not going to be another 15 months before the next thing from Narrative.

I always thought them living 24/7 at the Institute silly. I always considered it that they signed up to be a champion and when a match was coordinated a summons/message was sent requesting them to the Institute for the match.

This is how I pictured it working. Why would you sit around at the Institute unless you worked there or had to be there? Most champions have goals of their own and would probably want to be hard at work accomplishing them, most likely elsewhere.

I think it is funny that Jaredan missed the emphasized part of your post. It is easy for him/her to come here and cherry-pick the easy pro-riot statements, instead of diving into the vast waters of how much people hate this change in lore. Just saying though, it may seem like a good idea to Riot to put their head in the sand but this does nothing to build trust in their lore direction. If they want us to trust them, they should actually consider **NOT** going through with the proposed changes of divorcing the world from the game.

But again, Riot won't address any of these concerns, they'll shrug them off and focus on "positive" statements like these.

Even though the OP's point was that this was the first thing they've done right recently.

I didn't as much miss it as want to speak to moving forward.
We know there are concerns and consternation, a few of us have  expressed how we need to improve greatly on communication, execution and cadence when it comes to pure storytelling. 
We've made the changes to our approach to story because we genuinely believe it will allow us to do more and do better. 
I understand that you disagree, and it's our responsibility and privilege to produce content that can give you and our other players things to get excited about. 
The proof will be in the pudding, and I don't want to keep saying "trust us" as an answer. The answer will be in the story. It's down to us to work hard at earning trust, rather than asking for it, particularly when we might disagree on some things.

> I didn't as much miss it as want to speak to moving forward.
> We know there are concerns and consternation, a few of us have  expressed how we need to improve greatly on communication, execution and cadence when it comes to pure storytelling. 
> We've made the changes to our approach to story because we genuinely believe it will allow us to do more and do better.

> The proof will be in the pudding, and I don't want to keep saying "trust us" as an answer. The answer will be in the story. It's down to us to work hard at earning trust, rather than asking for it, particularly when we might disagree on some things.

Out of curiosity, since it seems to be a question everyone is begging to have answered. Why have you guys decided to push through the negative pushback on this decision, and force the community to accept what you are saying as far as narrative decision as "better" when, as you say, the community doesn't trust you.

Would it not be a good trust-building exercise to demonstrate your willingness to make amends or to set things right with the vocal lore-fans by rescinding this direction, and bringing the community into the folds as far as direction going forward?

I mean, we all get that popular opinion shouldn't affect something like balance or game design, because the game would look awful. But the flip side to that is why **shouldn't** we be allowed to have a say in the direction of lore?

The issue I'm seeing here is that from a narration perspective, you guys want to move forward. To look past JoJ, the IoW and other previous iterations of the lore at something bigger and better. But, if the community is against you on leaving those things behind, why is this something that is forced upon an unwilling community? And let me head off defenses such as "It is only a vocal minority of the  community." You have polling available to you. I am sure that you could send out plenty of surveys and test focus groups of people who play league and enjoy the lore. Don't use a defense that you can easily prove or disprove.

On a personal note, I am ok with some changes being made to narration going forward. I am not opposed to removing some older aspects of the lore to make it easier to move forward. What i am VEHEMENTLY against is the systematic, and complete refusal of your department to work with the community. It is constantly a situation where we are told "this is how things are going to be" and even under great pushback and negative opinion, you refuse to bend and accommodate the community and their wishes/desires.

I cannot stress enough that THIS is where you lose the trust and support of the community. If you are unwilling to work with us and work around the things we love and believe give character and heart to this MOBA, then no matter how amazing your direction is moving forward, you will NEVER be able to regain the trust that you subtly, but pointedly say doesn't matter to you by your actions and lack of regard for what the community wants.

You have a REAL chance to make changes here. You have had an overwhelmingly strong and negative opinion directed towards your new lore direction. Don't ignore this and say "it is part of a loud minority" Test your hypothesis. Use the data analysts you have in the office. Stop ignoring us as if we are screaming children angry at not getting a piece of candy because we aren't, and we deserve a give-and-take relationship with Riot. Not just one of "stomach this bitter pill because it is good for you and we know best"
